Variable name: Name of reference image for comparison in experiment
Definition: image_name_for_expt is the name of the reference image we want to compare against the experiment.
Description: This is the same as image_name from metamer_summary.tsv and all_metamer_summary.tsv, except with 'cone_' removed. This is because 'cone_' signifies that all the pixel values have been raised to the 1/3 to simulate the effect of the cones' nonlinear response. This was a pre-processing step we used, and for the experiment, we want to compare against the version of the image that is linear, i.e., the one whose pixel intensities are proportional to photon count. In order to do this, the images we show in the experiment have been post-processed so that all their pixel values have been raised to the 3rd power, undoing the cone nonlinearity.

Definition: image_1 is the random seed used for the generation of the first image presented in this trial, or 'reference', which signifies that this was the reference image (and thus had no random seed associated with it).

image_1 is the random seed used for the generation of the second image presented in this trial, or 'reference', which signifies that this was the reference image (and thus had no random seed associated with it).

image_1 is the random seed used for the generation of the third image presented in this trial, or 'reference', which signifies that this was the reference image (and thus had no random seed associated with it).

Allowed values: Any non-negative finite integer (no NaN or infinity)
Definition: trial_number is the index of this trial.
Description: Since this is python, the first trial has trial_number 0.

Definition: correct_response is the number the subject was supposed to press in order to have this trial deemed a 'hit'.
Description: The subject's task is to say whether image X matched image 1 or image 2, and press the corresponding key; this number is the key they were supposed to press, so it gives whether image X was a repeat of the first or second image.

Definition: The model name is the string which identifies which type of model to build.
Description: See the docstring of create_metamers.main() for more details on how this string is structured, but the string identifies the visual area we're modeling, the cone non-linearity, the window type, the number of scales to include (V1 only) and whether to normalize or not (V1 only). There are many more possible variants than the two given in Allowed values, but those are the only two used in this experiment. This should be the same for every trial in a given experiment.

Definition: Trial type tells us whether the two images compared on this trial were both metamers or whether one was a metamer.
Description: In most metamerism experiments, metamers are compared against each other. We also compare metamers against the reference image, and would like to be able to tell whether there's a difference in the resulting psychometric curves. column specifies which type of trial this was.

Allowed values: Any positive finite float (no NaN or infinity)
Definition: scaling gives the slope of the linear relationship between pooling window full-width half-maximum and eccentricity
Description: This is the model parameter that we're testing in our experiment, and we test 9 values for each model. It's inspired by the established linear relationship between neural receptive fields and eccentricity. As successive areas in the ventral stream have larger and larger scaling values, so too do the values we test: RGC has the smallest set of values, then V1, and then V2, but each successive model will have at least one scaling value that overlaps, for ease of comparison.

Definition: subject_response is the number the subject pressed on this trial.
hit_or_miss gives whether the trial's outcome was a hit or miss.
Description: A trial is a 'hit' when the subject is correct (so when subject_response and correct_response agree) and a 'miss' when the subject is incorrect (so when subject_response and correct_response disagree)

Allowed values: 'sub-%02d' % i, where i runs from 1 to 30, inclusive
Definition: subject_name is the name of the subject for this experimental session.
Description: Each subject sees every trial once per session. Each (subject, session) pair has a different random seed used to generate the presentation index.

Definition: session_number is the number of this experimental session
Description: Each subject has 3 sessions per model, in which they see all trials once; the sessions only differ in their presentation order.
